description.narrative:
Premiärministerns kontor har ansökt om finansiering för ett flerårigt stöd för förbättrat policyframtagande i Kosovo under perioden 2016-2019. Förslaget anger en förväntad kostnad av högst 30 000 000 svenska kronor (ca 3 240 000 Euro).
Den föreslagna insatsen ämnar påskynda och förbättra ett faktabaserat policyframtagande i Kosovo, genom att stärka koordineringssekretariatet (GCS) som sitter på premiärministerns kontor (OPM). GCS ansvarar för att förbereda och koordinera policyframtagandet, samt att kvalitetsäkra underligande policyanalys.
Insatsen ämnar förbättra policyframtagandet och koordineringskapaciteten genom att: 1.) Förbättra ramverket för policyframtagande, inklusive riktlinjer och manualer, och säkerställa att det inkluderar konsultationer med allmänheten och kvalitativa former av policyanalys; 2.) Utveckla GCS kapacitet att, i nära samarbete med det strategiska planeringskontoret, långsiktigt planera policyframtagande baserat på policyprioriteringar och linjeministeriernas strategiska planer; 3.) Öka linjeministeriernas kapacitet att bidra till policyframtagande; 4.) Förbättra kommunikation och koordinering under policyframtagandet.
Av den totala budgeten ska högst 8 600 000 SEK (ca 940 000EUR) finansiera projektaktiviteter implementerade av OPM, emedan kvarstående högst 21 400 000 SEK (ca 2 300 000 EUR) ska finansiera teknisk assistans upphandlad av ambassaden. Aktivitetsbudgeten inkluderar medel för projektrevision, en extern halvtidsöversyn och en ex-post utvärdering.

The Office of the Prime Minister has submitted a proposal for a multi-annual support for improving policy development in Kosovo during the period 2016-2019. The proposal outlines expected total costs of max 30 000 000 SEK( 3 240 000 EUR)
The proposed intervention aims to speed up and improve an evidence based policy development system in Kosovo, by strengthening the capacity of the Government Coordination Secretariat (GCS) in the Office of the Prime Minister (OPM). The GCS is responsible for preparing and coordinating the policy development, including quality assurance of underlying policy analysis.
The intervention aims to increase the policy development and coordination capacity by: 1.) Increasing the capacity at the line ministries to improve their input into the policy making process 2.) Developing the GCS’s capacity to, in close collaboration with the Strategic Planning Office (SPO), conduct forward planning for policy development, based on policy priorities and the line ministry’s strategic plan; 3.) Improving the policy development framework, including guidelines and manuals, ensuring an inclusion of public consultations and qualitative forms of policy analysis; and 4.) Improving communication on the policy development framework.
Out of the total budget max 8 600 000 SEK (940 000EUR) will be used for project activities implemented by the OPM while the remainder of max 21 400 000 SEK (2 300 000 EUR) will be used to finance technical assistance procured by the Embassy.

description.narrative: In spite of the political turmoil of the last twelve months, with less than two months in total with a government not being a care-taker government, things have been moving ahead at a relatively steady pace at OPM. Lots of different concept documents (the basis for laws and sub-legal acts) have been developed at line ministries supported by OPM using the guidelines produced earlier during the contribution. The main setback because of the political situation has been that several concept documents have not yet been approved by the government and/or Parliament. However, it is rather a question of when - not if - this will happen. Subsequently, it will lead to more coherent and improved policy development - the overall aim of the intervention. One of the most important concept documents developed is that of administrative burden reduction. This was approved by the government just before the outbreak of CoVID-19 and it is welcomed by political parties of different colours. The basic idea is to decrease unnecessary administrative tasks for citizens and businesses when dealing with public institutions, but also minimize administrative burden within and between ministries and agencies. This will be done over the course of several years by scrutinizing and updating/changing more than 400 laws. For the first part, the contact between citizens and businesses with public institutions, a specific tool ("the standard cost model") has been developed. This is used to identify bottlenecks in legal processes and how to remove these without jeopardizing the quality of public services. To decrease administrative burdens within the state administration, additional tools will probably be developed. Another important task has been to develop the Indicative Forward Work Plan (IFWP). The plan is developed on a three year basis, coordinating activities of all ministries. Previously, this has only been done on a one year basis (an annual work plan). However, because of the political instability regarding shifting governments and number of ministries, the IFWP has been changed/updated a couple of times and not yet been adopted by any government so far. Most likely, an updated version will be adopted by the incoming government in a couple of weeks' time. OPM has also continued its development of becoming less and less dependent of the external experts (PAi). The team leader of PAi has reduced working hours to approximately half compared to 2019 and some other Long Term Experts have done the same, indicating that OPM has built capacity during the contribution. CoVID-19 has had a negative impact on the contribution especially regarding trainings at line ministries, which have been postponed. Hopefully all trainings planned according to the work plan can be implemented during the second half of 2020. Already some trainings will take place the next couple of weeks, but with a lower number of participants than initially planned to ensure social distancing. CoVID-19 combined with the political uncertainty during spring 2020 has also had an effect on communication with OPM. With many employees working from home without having the adequate infrastructure to do so, communication has slowed down and both the financial report for 2020 and the terms of reference for the final evaluation have not yet been finalized.
